1866-01.Notes: Duse Mohamed Ali (sometimes also referred to as Duse Mohamad Ali, or alternately Duse Mohamed) was born in Alexandria but spent most of his life outside of his native Egypt.

1876-01.Notes: Duse Mohamed Ali (sometimes also referred to as Duse Mohamad Ali, or alternately Duse Mohamed) was born in Alexandria but spent most of his life outside of his native Egypt.

Participated in British Emancipation Day festivities at Rocky Point, Narrangansett Bay
Returned to Great Barrington, Massachussetts after visit to Alexander Du Bois

1885-09.Notes: Returned to Great Barrington, Massachussetts after visit to Alexander Du Bois
Moved to Nashville to attend Fiske University

1886-01.Notes: The exact dates of his New York trip are uknown. We do know that he traveled there as an actor as part of a theatre tour for Wilson Barret's Star Theatre Company. Duffield dates his arrival to NYC between 1886 and 188

1886-06.Notes: Moved to Nashville to attend Fiske University
Spent summer teaching in Wilson County, Tennessee

1886-08.Notes: Spent summer teaching in Wilson County, Tennessee

1887-01.Notes: The exact dates of his New York trip are uknown. We do know that he traveled there as an actor as part of a theatre tour for Wilson Barret's Star Theatre Company. Duffield dates his arrival to NYC between 1886 and 188
Between 1882 and the early 1900s Duse Mohamed Ali works as an itinerant actor and freelance journalist.

1887-08.Notes: Spent summer teaching in Wilson County, Tennesseee

1887-09.Notes: Returned to Fisk to finish degree

1888-06.Notes: Returned to Fisk to finish degree

1888-09.Notes: Moved to Cambridge, Massachusetts to attend Harvard University

1889-06.Notes: Moved to Cambridge, Massachusetts to attend Harvard University
Traveled in Massachusetts & Connecticut during Summer 1889, exact itinerary unknown

1889-08.Notes: Traveled in Massachusetts & Connecticut during Summer 1889, exact itinerary unknown

1889-09.Notes: Other sources identify his birthdate as 9-15-1890 and the birthplace as Sunny Ville, also in Clarendon Parish. Cooper says that McKay was born in Sunny Ville in 1890 and left at the age of 7.

1890-01.Notes: Traveled in Summer 1890, only known whereabout is Albany, where he visited half brother Adelbert, exact itinerary unknown
Returned to Cambridge by Fall 1890 for studies at Harvard

1891-01.Notes: Returned to Cambridge by Fall 1890 for studies at Harvard

1891-12.Notes: Returned to Cambridge for studies at Harvard

1892-01.Notes: Returned to Cambridge for studies at Harvard
While study at Harvard made efforts to reach out to other black college students in New England, details unknown except for visit to Amherst for a graduation ceremony

1892-04.Notes: Visited New York to speak with Slater Fund regarding graduate funding for PhD at University of Berlin
Returned to Cambridge for studies at Harvard

1892-07.Notes: Returned to Cambridge for studies at Harvard

1892-08.Notes: Arrives in Europe for studies via Rotterdam
Participated in seven-week German language intensive

1892-10.Notes: Participated in seven-week German language intensive

1896-01.Notes: Took up teaching position in Classics at Wilberforce University
Du Bois left Wilberforce for Philadelphia by August
Arrived summer 1896 for work on The Philadelphia Negro

In his memoir Leaves of an Active Life serialized in the Nigerian journal The Comet between 1937/06/12 and 1938/03/05, Ali recounts visiting the Caribbean and Florida in his early career, but does not provide specific dates; According to historian Ian Duffield this trip must have taken place sometimes in the early to mid 1890s.

1896-05.Notes: Trip to Ceder Rapids, Iowa to marry Nina Gomer
Du Bois left Wilberforce for Philadelphia by August

1897-01.Notes: Other sources identify his birthdate as 9-15-1890 and the birthplace as Sunny Ville, also in Clarendon Parish. Cooper says that McKay was born in Sunny Ville in 1890 and left at the age of 7.

1897-03.Notes: Attended startup meeting of Alexander Crummell's American Negro Academy & hoped to meet with U.S. Labor Commissioner about a job

1897-07.Notes: Returns to work in Philadelphia after academy meeting & visit to DC
Research study on black people in Farmville, VA
Presentation of research at Hampton Institute in Norfolk
Continued research study on black people in Farmville, VA

1897-08.Notes: Continued research study on black people in Farmville, VA
Continued research in Philadelphia for The Philadelphia Negro

1897-10.Notes: Continued research in Philadelphia for The Philadelphia Negro
Visit to Great Barrington, where Nina had given birth to son.
Rushed away from newborn and wife to Philadelphia after two days

1897-12.Notes: The Du Bois family celebrated Christmas in their new home in Atlanta where Du Bois began a teaching position at Atlanta University on January 1, 1898

1898-06.Notes: The Du Bois family celebrated Christmas in their new home in Atlanta where Du Bois began a teaching position at Atlanta University on January 1, 1898
Delivered commencement speechat Fisk on June 15, 1898
Returned to Atlanta University for work

1899-03.Notes: Returned to Atlanta University for work
Fundraising tour for Atlanta University in New England; meets Booker T. Washington

1899-05.Notes: Buries son Burghardt in Great Barrington, Massachusetts
Returns to Atlanta six days after burying son to preside over Atlanta Studies conference

1899-08.Notes: Returns to Atlanta six days after burying son to preside over Atlanta Studies conference
Attended National Afro-American Council meeting in Chicago where he defends Booker T. Washington

1900-02.Notes: Spent two days visiting Tuskegee University & Booker T. Washington, contemplating job there
Returned to Atlanta University deciding not to take Tuskeegee position
Attended meeting of Paris Exposition commissioners
Returned to Atlanta University to continue work

1900-03.Notes: Returned to Atlanta University deciding not to take Tuskeegee position
Returned to Atlanta University to continue work

1900-06.Notes: Returned to Atlanta University to continue work
Left for New York en route to Europe
Traveled to Europe for Paris Exposition for two months

1900-07.Notes: Traveled to Europe for Paris Exposition for two months
Attended First Pan-African Congress; do not have exact dates for London arrival/departure, just for the PAC itself

1903-08.Notes: Arrived several days after the "Boston Riot" on July 30,1903

1904-01.Notes: Went to Boston to fundraise for Atlanta University

1904-07.Notes: Attended Committee of Twelve meeting before resigning

1904-10.Notes: Spoke on October 18, 1904 to American Missionary Association

1906-08.Notes: Research for Census Bureau, late August-late September (was there when he learned of Atlanta Race Riot, September 22-24)

1906-09.Notes: Research for Census Bureau, late August-late September (was there when he learned of Atlanta Race Riot, September 22-24)
Rushed to Atlanta upon hearing news of riot

1906-11.Notes: Rushed to Atlanta upon hearing news of riot
Shuttled back and forth between Lowndes County and Atlanta in November 1906
Shuttled back and forth between Lowndes County and Atlanta in November 1907

1907-01.Notes: Fundraising tour for Atlanta University with Northern audiences
Enrolled in trade school in Kingston beginning in January 1907. The school was destroyed by the earthquake on January 14, 1907.
Worked as an apprentice to a master craftsman for two years. It was here that he met Walter Jekyll.

1907-02.Notes: Fundraising tour for Atlanta University with Northern audiences

1907-04.Notes: Spent three weeks in Washington trying to work with Census Bureau

1907-08.Notes: Third Niagara Movement Meeting (end of August)

1908-05.Notes: Spoke at New York's Republican club

1909-01.Notes: Worked as an apprentice to a master craftsman for two years. It was here that he met Walter Jekyll.

1909-06.Notes: Born in hospital in Chicago, Illinois but family lived in Glen Ellyn. Beckford has birth at as 1912 and departure to Chicago at age of 5, but Aschenbrenner concords with other sources on 1909 date of birth. Exact dates of childhood residence need further clarification.

1910-03.Notes: Public address in favor of NAACP

1910-08.Notes: Resigned from Atlanta University to work for NAACP

1911-01.Notes: Attends the Universal Races Congress with W.E.B. Du Bois and other leading intellectuals of the time. Sets up an office at 158 Fleet Street in London and founds the African Times and Orient Review (1912-1920)

1911-06.Notes: Addressed the Lyceum Club, stayed until late summer

1911-07.Notes: Addressed the Lyceum Club, stayed until late summer

1914-01.Notes: Born in hospital in Chicago, Illinois but family lived in Glen Ellyn. Beckford has birth at as 1912 and departure to Chicago at age of 5, but Aschenbrenner concords with other sources on 1909 date of birth. Exact dates of childhood residence need further clarification.

1916-01.Notes: "I worked as a janitor and houseman at the D.K.E. House and the Hanover Inn from 1915 until the spring of 1916, and my only connection with the college was that I used to go to the library at night sometimes to read.” Letter to Harold Rugg, librarian at Dartmouth, 1921. Papers of Harold Rugg-Dartmouth College.

1921-01.Notes: Attends the Universal Races Congress with W.E.B. Du Bois and other leading intellectuals of the time. Sets up an office at 158 Fleet Street in London and founds the African Times and Orient Review (1912-1920)

Originally traveled to NYC for a business meeting about cacao import but ended up staying for ten years. While in the US, he became a regular contributor to Garvey's Negro World and head ed UNIA's African Affairs department between 1922-1924. Ali would leave the UNIA by the end of 1924, some months before Garvey's arrest in 1925. After spending a few years in the Midwest, he returned to New York in 1926 and helped found a cultural organization by the name of America-Asia Association Inc

1921-09.Notes: Left immediately after Pan-African Congress, which ended September 6, 1921
Vacation, likely with lover & mentee Jessie Fausett

1922-01.Notes: During his stay in Detroit, Duse Mohamed Ali founded the Detroit Central Islamic Society, which Duffield argues was loosely based on the London Central Islamic Society. In 1925 he went on to found the American Asiatic Society, which he then left in 1926.

1922-10.Notes: Attended Fourth Congress of the Communist International

1923-01.Notes: In the early 1920s, Ali founded the Ämericän' African Oriental Trading Company whose businesses are based in Chicago. According to Duffield, the address of this Company was 3202-Cottage Grove Avenue, Chicago.

1930-01.Notes: Meets Mark Turbyfill at Mary Hunter's Apartment

1930-02.Notes: Runs a ballet school with Mary Turbyfill

1930-03.Notes: Essie and Paul went on a concert tour in Scotland in late March. No return date given but most likely March or April 1930

1931-01.Notes: Runs a ballet school with Mary Turbyfill
Launch of League for Independent Political Action

Originally traveled to NYC for a business meeting about cacao import but ended up staying for ten years. While in the US, he became a regular contributor to Garvey's Negro World and head ed UNIA's African Affairs department between 1922-1924. Ali would leave the UNIA by the end of 1924, some months before Garvey's arrest in 1925. After spending a few years in the Midwest, he returned to New York in 1926 and helped found a cultural organization by the name of America-Asia Association Inc

Ali emigrates to Nigeria in 1931, where he first works as a contributor for The Nigerian Daily Times, and then as the editor for the Nigerian Daily Telegraph. In July 1933 he founded the journal The Comet, which he edited until his death in 1945.

1931-09.Notes: Essie was in Kitzbuhel for 2 months
We do not know the reason for this visit.

1931-11.Notes: Essie was in Kitzbuhel for 2 months
Celebration of 21st anniversary of The Crisis

1932-03.Notes: Two weeks of lectures at Atlanta University

1932-12.Notes: Negro Dance Group (which Dunham co-directs with Ludmila Speranzeva) performs at the Chicago Beaux Arts Ball, which Chicago Daily News calls "the first Negro ballet ever danced."

1933-01.Notes: Moved to Atlanta to take professorship at Atlanta University Center

1933-03.Notes: Moved to Atlanta to take professorship at Atlanta University Center

1933-05.Notes: Addressed Conference on the Economic Status of the Negro

1934-12.Notes: Daylong layover in Berlin en route from London to Moscow

1936-08.Notes: Was in Paris for a week

1937-01.Notes: Returned from Europe & Asia; second week of January 1937 (Lewis, Fight 422)

1937-03.Notes: Performs as part of Negro Dance Evening at the Young Men's Hebrew Association

1938-01.Notes: Date of return to England unclear
L'Ag'ya performed at Federal Theatre in Chicago; Dunham appointed Director of the Negro Unit of the Chicago Branch of the Federal Theatre Project

1938-02.Notes: L'Ag'ya performed at Federal Theatre in Chicago; Dunham appointed Director of the Negro Unit of the Chicago Branch of the Federal Theatre Project

1938-04.Notes: Performs for Haitian Minister at the Haitian Coffee Festival in Washington, D.C.

1938-06.Notes: Performs at Benefit for Children in Spanish War Area, sponsored by Medical Bureau to Aid Spanish Democracy. Repeated 8 Oct 1938

1940-02.Notes: Premiers Tropics and Le Jazz "Hot" at the Windsor Theater; runs for 12 Sundays; Dunham proclaimed founder of a new genre: "Negro Dance"

1940-04.Notes: Premiers Tropics and Le Jazz "Hot" at the Windsor Theater; runs for 12 Sundays; Dunham proclaimed founder of a new genre: "Negro Dance"

1945-01.Notes: Ali emigrates to Nigeria in 1931, where he first works as a contributor for The Nigerian Daily Times, and then as the editor for the Nigerian Daily Telegraph. In July 1933 he founded the journal The Comet, which he edited until his death in 1945.

1994-01.Notes: Attended celebration for birth of Ngũgĩ wa Thiong'o's child (Spring 1994)

1994-12.Notes: Lamming says in a letter to Dorothy Figueroa that he returned to London in December. Letter dated February

2005-01.Notes: Flight itinerary gives departure date. 2006 appointment book not entirely clear about where he is for the first half of the year, but it is most likely Barbados
